awd_titl_txt: Investigation of mass and heat transport and sustainability of the novel  thermally driven membrane distillation crystallization process
awd_abstract_narration:
1236846
Cath

When considering one of the more popular desalination processes, reverse osmosis, practical water recovery in seawater desalination is hydraulically limited to approximately 60 percent, and in brackish water desalination, recovery is limited to approximately 80 percent by mineral scale formation. Restricted water recovery and increasing energy demand at higher recoveries might limit further improvement of currently used membrane desalination technologies. Distillation processes, and specifically membrane processes that utilize vapor pressure as a driving force, are not limited by the osmotic pressure of feed or brine streams, and might be a solution to overcome the limitations of current desalination processes.
 
Thus, the main objective of this research is to comprehensively investigate heat and mass transport in novel membrane distillation crystallization processes in which water is sustainably desalinated from supersaturated feed solutions and minerals can be simultaneously recovered for beneficial use.
 
The research focuses on measuring the rates of formation, size distribution, adhesion to membranes, and removal/harvesting of mineral crystals that form during desalination of water containing sparingly soluble salts. It also investigates the effects of operating conditions and environments on the sustainable production of purified water and minerals using the membrane distillation crystallization process.  Controlled laboratory experiments will be carried out in which a rigorous scientific approach will be applied to identify, characterize, and quantify the individual and combined mechanisms controlling bulk and surface crystallization and their effects on heat and mass transport through the membrane.  In particular, the focus of the research will be to identify the optimal operating conditions under which this hybrid desalination and mineral recovery process can be sustainably operated under supersaturated conditions to produce water and produce valuable mineral.  Through the analytical methods and quantitative tools that will be developed as part of this research, improvements will be made to the current understanding of the fundamental principles and mechanisms involved in evaporation of water through scale layers followed by porous synthetic membranes. These will help the application of this knowledge in the modeling and design of small and large engineered systems.

Limited water recovery in existing desalination processes is the cause for elevated operating costs of desalination.  This research will address the global need to increase water availability through the constant improvement of technologies that produce water at higher quality, lower energy demand, using renewable sources of energy, and without harming the environment.  Understanding the mechanisms of reversible and repeatable membrane fouling scaling when treating supersaturated solutions by thermally driven membrane processes will mitigate one of the main problems encountered in desalination of saline water.  Ultimately, the goal of this research is to improve our ability to provide clean water at an affordable cost to the public in modern and developing countries.  The results will also facilitate the design of better treatment processes to reduce the discharge of brines to the environment and increase the reliance on natural resources, such as solar energy, for desalination.  The research and educational plan will support the participation of undergraduate and graduate science and engineering students, and specifically from underrepresented groups/minorities in research and education.  The development of interactive lecture and hands-on activities, and the establishment of continued education programs for pre-college teachers will enhance the interests of their students in science, engineering, and the environment, and will hopefully direct more motivated students to pursue higher education in environmental engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Sustainable access to clean, safe water supplies is of paramount importance to society and has been described as a fundamental human right. Yet, this most basic necessity for life is increasingly threatened all over the world, as demand for water grows and conventional water resources are depleted or contaminated. Many communities are now facing increased reliance on nonconventional water resources that are high in salinity and require desalination, such as seawater or brackish groundwater. Desalination is inherently energy intensive and complicated by the fact that most natural water resources also contain minerals. In the same way that these minerals form deposits in domestic hot water heaters and kettles, they can also form a hard scale on the equipment used for desalination. This scale can be very difficult to clean and further inhibits the efficiency of desalination processes. Exacerbating this issue is the fact that most desalination technologies actually function by removing pure water from the salt water, resulting in concentration of the salts and minerals and effectively limiting the maximum concentration that may be treated by these technologies.

The overall objective of this project was to investigate the performance, efficiency, and overall sustainability of a separation process called membrane distillation applied to desalination of hypersaline brines, which is water containing very high salt and mineral content. The process uses special porous, hydrophobic membranes similar to Gore-Tex® that block the passage of liquid water but allow water vapor to pass freely. In membrane distillation, water evaporates from heated brine on one side of the membrane and condenses into the chilled distilled water on the other side of the membrane, leaving salts and minerals behind. The advantage of this process over other distillation processes is that it works at low temperatures, allowing practically any heat supply to be used as an energy source. Also, it has specific advantages over reverse osmosis, which is the dominant desalination process currently available. Reverse osmosis functions by physically forcing water through a semi-permeable membrane by applying pressure greater than the osmotic pressure difference between the feed and permeate streams. Because the salts in the brine being treated are concentrated during the process, it requires higher pressure and therefore more energy to continue the process as it progresses until ultimately a maximum concentration is reached.

In this project, we demonstrated the capabilities of membrane distillation to produce distilled water from the Great Salt Lake until sodium chloride (table salt) crystallized in the solution at a concentration of about ten times the salinity of seawater. This was accomplished despite the presence of other minerals in the water with the potential for scaling and with only a modest decline in efficiency. No other available membrane technology is capable of desalinating such highly concentrated brine, and these results have implications not only for water treatment but also the possibility of mineral production from brine as well.

Brackish groundwater and geothermal brines are other potentially available water resources which can be difficult to utilize due to high mineral content, silica in particular. In this project we investigated the behavior of silica when concentrated using membrane distillation, and what happens when water containing silica is concentrated to the point that scale begins to form. We also tested nanofiltration, which is a pressure-driven membrane process, under similar conditions for comparison. We found that both processes were effective for removing silica up to concentrations exceeding its solubility limit, and although eventually a scale layer on the membrane surface would form it could be managed effectively with periodic cleaning. However, nanofiltration did not completely reject sodium chloride and performance was greatly reduced with even a slight increase in salinity. Therefore, we concluded that the membrane distillation has key advantages compared to nanofiltration for treating brines high in both salinity and silica content.

A third major outcome of this project was the development of a novel theoretical method to assess physical properties important for a membrane’s potential for use in membrane distillation. Most existing theoretical models for membrane distillation require knowledge of inherent membrane properties which may not be known or are not able to be measured accurately. The novel method we developed uses only data collected directly from membrane distillation experiments, and even has the capability to estimate certain unknown membrane properties if other properties are known. As part of this development, a large selection of almost a dozen membranes were tested under carefully controlled conditions. This method and its associated data should provide helpful insight regarding what characteristics are desired for membrane distillation, as well as providing a relatively simple way to measure those characteristics.
